newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan government budget may rise 4.1 pct in 97/98.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan government budget may rise 4.1 pct in 97/98.

text.p: Taiwan's central government budget may increase by 4.1 percent in fiscal 1997/98 (July/June), and the government hopes to reach a balanced budget in fiscal 2000/01, a government statement said on Tuesday.
The 1997/98 budget will rise 4.1 percent to T$1.244 trillion from a year earlier, the cabinet's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said in a statement.
"A cabinet sub-meeting just preliminarily passed the proposal to increase the budget by 4.1 percent," the statement said.
"In order to reach a balanced budget in fiscal 2000/01, we don't expect room for the central government budget to rise sharply in the future," it said.
The budget would not be finalised until parliamentary approval, scheduled for March 1997, a directorate spokeswoman said.
In fiscal 1996/97, the central government budget still had a deficit of T$155.8 billion, she said.

For fiscal 1997/98, the government hopes to reach gross domestic product growth of 6.3 percent, consumer price index growth of 3.1 percent, a jobless rate of 2.7 percent, and a trade surplus of US$7 billion, she added.
These follow earlier forecasts for fiscal 1996/97, with GDP growth at 6.4 percent, CPI growth at 3.3 percent, the jobless rate at 2.6 percent, and a trade surplus of US$8.9 billion, she said.
